name: Battlestations Pacific
description: Experience one war through two epic sagas where you will be a part of history or change it. Feel the power of the historically authentic and decisive battles of the Pacific War. Relive some of the grandest and most critical naval battles of recent history and for the first time, choose to lead your fleet to a completely different ending...

reviews.review_text: Following up on Battlestations: Midway, Battlestations: Pacific keeps the same mix of RTS and action together. This time the game has 2 campaigns, one for the Japanese and one for the US putting you right in the middle of large naval battles in the Pacific. Gameplay is the same giving you a large tactical view of all of your units and allows you once again to take command of any unit at anytime to let you control the action first hand.

An extreamly underated game. Nothing beats diving through a cloud of AA fire on a torpedo run agaisnt a american or japanse carrier. Or the the feeling of invicibility as you pound enemy ships with you main guns as a battleship or shoot an enemy squadron from the sky with your flak guns.
Destroying IJN Kongou and Yamato with Patrol Boat  10/10

I have been looking for so many years for a game like this. Battlestations: Pacific gives me more than I even wished for. This game is the best I have ever purchased in two years. This game gives you command of your own ship, then throws you into the heat of the battle. If you are looking for an excellent RTS, this is the game for you.  I recommend NOT using it on a Windows 7, for it runs insanely slow. Windows 8 works perfectly.

Combining elements of ship/sub warfare, arcade flight simulator and real time tactics. The single player missions range from a mini-sub attack on Sydney Harbour, through to full fleet invasions involving multiple aircraft carriers and associated battlegroups. There is slightly more emphasis on flight compared to the previous title. There are some artefacts that creep in to illustrate that this is a console port, the ship guns now autocompute range and lead, but this is offset by the ships now having subtargets (fuel, engine, magazne, etc) that you can aim for. The control scheme isn't as good as the previous native title, but it is passable. The only really annoying oversight is that there is no way to assign aircraft rudder to the twist action of a joystick. There are some interesting new units, the kaiten torpedo (plays like a manually guided torp), the LSM(R), Ohka (kamikazi rocket bomb).

Who hasn't spent their days thinking about how much fun it would be to bomb Pearl Harbour? Unless you're a 90 year old Japanese man, this is the only way that you can experience it. I haven't shot down this many Americans since the last time I went to a bar in Portland.

i absolutely love this game to death. i keep coming back for more everytime i log on. everything about this game is a masterpiece from the graphics to the ships to the planes battlestations pacific is a truely wonderful game. although i was hoping that the battleships could open fire on each other from miles out i guess this isnt meant to be a full on simulator of ship vs ship battles. i was also hoping for a way to get the pearl harbor battleships and to play as them after they've been raised and rebuilt from there watery grave at pearl harbor but i guess that isnt going to happen either. but anyway i would say to get this game you will not be dissapointed.  my only problems with the game is how the battleships cant fire off all there guns at once and how the ai loves to spam the most powerful units, that is frustrating. also how in multiplayer the planes dont actually launch from there carriers they spawn above it. other then that the game is perfect. this game is really fun either way and i cant recommend it enough.you can fly planes, steer ships, capture island bases, launch recon planes, use submarines, drop destroyer depth charges to kill subs underwater, launch planes from carriers, change the planes payload when selecting your aircraft and there is so much more to do in this game.   there are two campaigns in this the american campaign which takes place after the battle of midway and starts off with the battle of the eastern solomons, and a fictional japanese campaign which starts off at the attack on pearl harbor. both campaigns require a lot of skill and effort to finally complete especially the last mission, and there are also 3 difficulty levels to choose from rookie, regular and veteran. both campaigns have a set number of main objectives you have to complete as well as the hidden objectives in order to get a gold medal on them. if you get a gold medal on certain missions you will unlock new units something that is definitely missing from todays games.

Arcade-yet-not   Okay, so you get super quick repair times, except when you are more damaged it repairs less per second, as in, not only is there more to repair but it takes longer with 2 factors.   Aiming is pretty easy, but armor is very effective so dont think 'Hey, all my shots hit the big ship! its dead'  Nope. Maybe 1/16th of its health gone.   If you like sinking stuff, training mode is probably the best for you....nothing fires back except 3 ships in naval mode...   Bombing is relatively easy, just hold shift or whatever it was, and when the targets about to hit the ship, FIRE!   Overall:  PROS -Good graphics -Easy to learn -Soft on beginners -Great cutscenes, I feel like I'm in an interactive movie! -Controls are not over-the-top reactive  CONS -LONG Cutscenes, mainly in practice this is a problem -Ship damage listing wise is not good -Windows live seems to not let me make an account (you need it for cloud saving) -Windows live in general  Play if you like somewhat arcadey games with a good story. Absolutely amazing game that combines RTS and action elements that put you right at the heart of the largest sea war in human history. Every mission is masterfully crafted with no glitches or bugs that I have seen yet. The graphics are nothing to write home about, but on the flipside this game will run wonderfully on the worst computers this world can offer. In short this game is the living proof that gameplay design retains its luster even 6 years after its release date and few games to my knowledge have done so.  A 10/10 would even begin to do this game due credit and I would saw off my left pinkie for a sequel.

For everyone who wants to save their progress but doesn't have an xbox live account here's a way to save without paying $60 (granted, you can't play offline)  -Press home and click 'create profile'  -scroll down and click 'create local account'  -follow the steps  -there you go!  Your progress saves so you can now play with the glorious Yamato once you unlock it!

Fun game with planes, boats and the like. For the windows live part that people are complaining about, simply do the following. When you load the game and are prompted by windows live, click new profile, scroll down the text that appears and click the 'local profile' link in the text itself. Create and done. Its a bit hidden, but now you can save. Done and done. Midway doesnt have to worry about the Windows Live thing.
